passages.text: 2025 rev guided down on speaker 3Q25 outlook, but solid progress in auto server to drive 2026 growth

On its 2Q25 earnings call, management guided down its 2025 revenue from the previous \(20\%\) YoY growth target, which we think was well expected, but its 3Q25 outlook is weaker than expected due to ongoing uncertainties in some segments, despite overall demand gradually bottoming out. The bright spot of the call was the company's automotive growth potential, which could be driven by a significant content increase and continued rising product adoption in both China and international customers. Also, its server business may start to see more meaningful contribution from 2026 with breakthroughs in ASIC customers/projects. Thus, we stay OW as we think investors will gradually shift focus to Silergy's longer- term outlook after reflecting on the softer near- term outlook.

Weaker 3Q25 demand outlook, but stabilized GM. Management guides its 3Q25 revenue to be flat or slightly up QoQ, as the recent order momentum from some customers remains conservative (especially consumer, NB computing and traditional industrial segments), although the overall PMIC industry inventory destocking process seems to have come to an end. Given the weaker near- term outlook, we revise down our 2H25 estimates, and our new 2025 full- year revenue growth forecast is only \(2\%\) YoY now, in line with the company's guidance cut from the previous \(20\%\) YoY growth. With more stabilized pricing and growing penetration in higher end platforms, we believe the company's GM could return to the \(53 - 54\%\) level in 2H25.

Solid 2026 outlook driven by meaningful auto content growth and server business breakthrough. As we highlighted in our previous report (link), we believe the company's automotive business could drive its revenue next year, with the revenue mix expected to reach \(15 - 20\%\) (from \(12 - 15\%\) in 2025), thanks to 1) the doubling of content increase from US \(150 in 2025 to potentially US\) 300 in 2026, with new high- end products entering mass production (e.g. MCU and BMC), 2) expanding customer base and model adoption in the China market, and 3) more design- in projects from international customers that could gradually contribute to revenue from 2H26. On the other hand, management expects its server revenue to reach \(5\%\) in 2026, driven by more ASIC customers (both CSPs and server OEMs) project ramp next year, and potentially more contribution in 2027 if the higher content v- core product gets qualified by a major client customer.

Implications. We lower our 2025E, 2026E and 2027E EPS by \(7\%\) , \(10\%\) and \(4\%\) to NT\$7.0, NT\$13.0 and NT\$18.5, after factoring in weaker revenue momentum. Hence, our Jun- 26 PT is lowered slightly to NT\$470 (from NT \$500), based on 30x 2H26- 1H27E P/E, largely in line with its historical median P/E.

Silergy has continued its business transformation to auto/server and improved production technology (Gen 4 platform; advanced packaging; testing). Growing R&D investment during the downturn has helped the company widen the gap vs. Chinese peers, which will also support more high-end project wins, in our view, especially when the upcycle returns. Maintain OW.
Our Jun- 26 PT of NT\$470 is based on a 30x 2H26- 1H27E P/E, largely in line with the historical median 12M fwd P/E.

PMIC demand seems to be bottoming out. We previously expected 2Q25 to be a significant growth quarter. However, given the tariff situation, some projects have been postponed by customers. But now, inventory correction has come to an end now for most applications. In 2H25, each market's demand:

Consumer: demand may not be very strong, demand will be postponed to later quarters. Computer: demand will remain relatively muted. Auto: demand uptick in both China and non- China markets. Server: continued strength in datacenter (power supply, server MB, storage and optical module). Industrial: may not see revenue uptick in the near- term (emerging business is growing, but traditional business remains weak, e.g. meter demand is weak), but should see revenue recovery in 2026.

Although we cannot meet our previous \(20\%\) YoY growth guidance, we still expect YoY growth in 2025. Both rush orders and postponed orders have been seen recently, which creates near- term demand uncertainties.
Yes, it will be driven by auto content growth, expanding customer base, new design- in AI/HPC server projects.
Revenue is expected to be flat to slight QoQ growth. GM will be stable with stabilized pricing and product mix. Overall profitability will be healthy.
There were one- time manufacturing costs due to rush orders made in different factories.
Q: Was 2Q25 GM impacted by FX? What is the 2H25 GM outlook?
- Limited impact from FX, as our functional currency is USD.- 2H25 GM is expected to return to previous levels.

- Stable in 1Q-2Q25; upcoming quarters expected to maintain stability.- Biggest R&D investment in auto with \(\sim 50\%\) allocation, and \(20 - 25\%\) is in AI server, while the rest is for consumer and industrial.
- No, we will not, as we focus on gaining share now.- Also, our growing high-end platform penetration could maintain our GM.

- SSD demand has remained strong in datacenter applications, but some traditional brands are still digesting inventory.- Industrial demand is mixed: renewables demand is recovering, while traditional demand remains weak.

- Demand for TV sets, residential lighting and audio equipment was weaker than prior customer forecasts made at the end of 2024.- Big brands that have a bigger exposure to the US market have strategies to lower inventory build.- China stimulus is beneficial to us in 1H25, but we expect it to lose steam in 2H25.

- Auto is \(12 - 15\%\) of the revenue mix in 2025.- International customers' outlook is not positive, but we are still securing new designs in projects from international markets.- In the China market, our auto business is expanding into more brands and models, and our customer coverage is also increasing.- 2026 auto mix is expected to reach \(15 - 20\%\) .

- Auto EV remains a growth segment, though with tougher competition (e.g. EVs are now cheaper than traditional cars).- But we are not seeing pricing pressure in new products. Old products face higher pressure.- The main bottleneck for us is still the supply chain tightness, so we will continue to
allocate more capacity to auto products. We will also have international capacity for auto products soon.

We have expanded our offerings in BMS, MCU families. For example, we recently introduced a high- end RISC- V based MCU for auto safety applications. We now cover more products, from mostly generic applications (e.g. DC- DC) to specific applications (e.g. safety PMIC, ADAS PMIC).
Auto dollar content is reaching US \(150 now; it can increase to US\) 300 by the end of 2026. Thus, there is increasing customer interest in our product portfolio.

Lower- end suppliers are the ones to impose pricing pressure, but actually they can't deliver higher entry barrier products. We have better cost structure vs those smaller local suppliers with our Gen4 platforms, and we also build in- house testing facilities to reduce cost. Hence, auto is actually one of the highest- GM product segments.
2- 4 years for auto projects. AI projects generally take - 3 years.
ASIC has seen some progress in CSP and server OEM customers. For AMD, we have not seen significant progress. Revenue is possible to reach \(5\%\) mix next year.

Our previous expected ramp time is 2H25, but some customer delays will affect our target, so we may reach \(10\%\) 1- 2 quarters later. Target is still reachable, but timing will depend on customers' adoption speed.

- China market demand and growth is better than non-China markets.- However, the demand for low-end products for the US market is weak.- Stronger demand from China market lies in the computing, renewables, and auto sectors.

- Some Gen2 products may lose share if they are not refreshed.- We will continue to refresh specific products on new platforms for long-term applications.- Our strategy is to maintain our GM and competitive edge, instead of following the aggressive pricing.
- MPS excels in high-efficiency power IC products, which helps it enter into AI server and auto ADAS markets.- Silergy is closing the gap now, but it is uncertain when it will catch up.
- Big customers prefer total solution providers.- Silergy is transforming into a total solution provider with integrated products.
- SG Micro's GM is decent, so we think it should be a good company.- But we do not see much competition from SG Micro, as Silergy's share in China is \(

Silergy Corp (Overweight; Price Target: NT\$470.00)

Silergy has continued its business transformation to auto/server and improved production technology (Gen 4 platform; advanced packaging; testing). Growing R&D investment during the downturn has helped the company widen the gap vs. Chinese peers, which will also support more high- end project wins, in our view, especially when the upcycle returns. Maintain OW.
Our Jun- 26 PT of NT\$470 is based on a 30x 2H26- 1H27E P/E, largely in line with the historical median 12M fwd P/E.
